Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Increasing Production of Palladium Supported on Hierarchically Porous Monolithic Carbon Catalysts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is that the palladium on hierarchically porous monolithic carbon catalyst being developed promises longer lifetimes and higher performance to industrial chemical companies. This more active, more selective catalyst can lower the operating temperature in chemical reactions thereby decreasing energy usage and giving products with fewer impurities, requiring a smaller number of purification steps and producing less waste. Success will therefore impact both ecological and commercial sustainability in the chemical industry.

The objectives of this Phase II research project are 1) demonstrate that the carbon support is scalable while maintaining the mechanical properties needed for industrial use, 2) scale loading the palladium catalyst onto the support, 3) exhibit the same high catalytic performance as the laboratory prepared catalyst, and 4) enter full scale production while setting up a quality system. The catalyst to be produced at large quantities represents the first of a new class of hierarchically porous catalyst supports and so further validation of this new product will provide the foundation for introduction of a broad class of catalysts with these superior properties. If successful, full scale manufacturing of this new class of catalysts will be pursued.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this Phase II research was to design a commercial process for producing hierarchically porous, carbon supported catalysts capable of supplying product at the industrial scale of 50+ Tons. The initial target was a palladium on hierarchically porous carbon catalyst which demonstrated superior performance when compared to other commercially available catalysts in the NSF Phase I SBIR research. The initial objectives were defined as 1) demonstrate that the carbon support is scalable while maintaining the mechanical properties needed for industrial use, 2) scale loading the palladium catalyst onto the support, 3) exhibit the same high catalytic performance as the laboratory prepared catalyst, and 4) enter full scale production while setting up a quality system. The research carried out under this Phase II award was successful. A new commercial process for producing hierarchically porous carbon was designed and a provisional patent has been filed. This process represents the first continuous production method for this class of materials. The final catalyst exhibits the desired mechanical properties and the same high catalytic performance demonstrated in Phase I. Quality control specifications have been identified and ASTM approved methods of measurement have been established. Full scale production plans are being carried out on the 100+ Ton per year scale.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project is that hierarchically porous, carbon supported catalysts promise longer lifetimes and higher performance in industrial chemical reactions. These more active, more selective catalysts lower the operating temperature in chemical reactions thereby decreasing energy usage and giving products with fewer impurities, requiring a smaller number of purification steps and producing less waste. In many reactions these catalysts use significantly less precious metal than the competitions’ catalysts. Moreover, we have discovered that there are some reactions where the carbon itself, without any metal, can be used as a highly effective, stable catalyst. Our successful scale-up efforts have impacted the industry by enabling the commercialization of new, greener processes for producing commodity chemicals. We are working with industrial partners to implement these new catalysts into their commercial processes.

 


Last Modified: 12/10/2019
Modified by: Franchessa M Sayler
